name: 2-1-1 Arizona
description: 2-1-1 Arizona is a comprehensive information and referral service that connects individuals and families to over 8,500 local and statewide resources. The service helps people find assistance with basic needs, housing, utilities, food, healthcare, employment, and other essential services.
contactInfo: Phone: Dial 2-1-1 within Arizona | 877-211-8661 from anywhere | Fax: 602-263-0979 | Arizona Relay: 7-1-1 or 800-367-8939 | Address: 1275 W. Washington St. Suite 210, Tempe, AZ 85288
eligibility: All Arizona residents
notes: Available by phone from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. Monday through Friday. Website search available 24/7. Cannot help people in person at their office.

name: A New Leaf - Domestic Violence Services
description: A New Leaf provides emergency shelter and comprehensive support services for victims of domestic violence in Mesa and surrounding areas, offering a safe environment and resources to help survivors rebuild their lives.
eligibility: Victims of domestic violence and their children
serviceArea: City-specific (Mesa) with services available to East Valley residents
notes: Services include emergency shelter, counseling services, legal and financial assistance, housing services, support services, children's services, and community educational services. Hours of operation: Monday-Friday 8:00 am - 5:00 pm, Closed Saturday and Sunday.

name: A New Leaf Housing and Shelter Services
description: A comprehensive program providing direct shelter, long-term housing, affordable housing, and support services to individuals and families experiencing or at risk of homelessness in Mesa and surrounding areas.
contactInfo: Family Housing Hub: (877) 211-8661 | Individual Services: (877) 211-8661
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness
serviceArea: County-wide (Maricopa) with services in Mesa, Surprise, Phoenix, Apache Junction, and Glendale
notes: Services include homeless shelters, affordable housing solutions, and rent/utility assistance. The organization provides comprehensive support to help clients regain stability and independence.

name: Ability360
description: Ability360 advocates personal responsibility by, and for, people with disabilities as a means to independence. Offers comprehensive programs including independent living skills instruction, information and referral, peer support, advocacy, home modification, and employment services.
contactInfo: Main Office: 5025 E. Washington St., Ste. 200, Phoenix, AZ 85034 | Phone: (602) 256-2245 | Toll Free: (800) 280-2245 | Email: info@ability360.org | AZ Relay Service: 7-1-1
eligibility: People with disabilities in Maricopa County and surrounding areas
serviceArea: County-wide (Maricopa) with additional offices in Mesa, Glendale, Coolidge, and Tucson
notes: Ability360 is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that began in 1977 as the Arizona Congress for Action. Services include home care, employment assistance, ADA training, and recreation through the Ability360 Sports & Fitness Center.

name: Arizona Coalition to End Sexual and Domestic Violence Helpline
description: The Arizona Sexual and Domestic Violence Helpline provides support, information, and referrals about sexual and domestic violence as well as assistance navigating the legal system. The helpline offers multiple contact methods including phone, chat, SMS, and email.
contactInfo: Phone: (602) 279-2980 or (800) 782-6400 | Arizona Relay Service: 7-1-1
eligibility: Anyone affected by sexual or domestic violence in Arizona
notes: Hours: Monday 8:30-5, Tuesday 8:30-7, Wednesday 8:30-5, Thursday 8:30-5, Friday 8:30-5. Additional 24-hour hotlines are available through partner organizations.

name: Arizona Immigrant and Refugee Services (AIRS)
description: A 501(c)(3) non-profit organization providing social, economic, and educational services to refugees and immigrants in Maricopa County, including housing, food, clothing, translation, English language instruction, job training, employment assistance, and immigration services.
contactInfo: Office Hours: Monday - Friday, 9:00 AM - 4:30 PM | Email: info@airsaz.org
eligibility: Recently arrived refugees and legal immigrants in Maricopa County
notes: Services include immigration specialist assistance (relative petitions, citizenship, permanent residency, document replacement), monthly classes (financial, police training, hygiene & health, public transportation), and special services for Special Immigrant Visa holders (SIVs).

name: Autumn House Domestic Violence Shelter
description: A dedicated domestic violence shelter in Mesa providing emergency shelter and comprehensive support services for victims of domestic violence, with a DV-focused program that offers a safe environment and resources to help survivors rebuild their lives.
eligibility: Victims of domestic violence and their children
serviceArea: City-specific (Mesa) with services available to East Valley residents
notes: Services include emergency services (8), support services (4), children's services (5), community educational services (1), legal and financial assistance services (1), and housing services (1). Available 24/7 for emergency shelter needs.

name: Arizona Attorney General Resources for Seniors
description: A comprehensive directory of resources for seniors in Arizona, providing information on elder abuse reporting, care facilities, legal services, business licensing, and agencies offering programs for seniors.
contactInfo: Office of the Arizona Attorney General: (602) 542-2124 | Email: seniorabuse@azag.gov | Adult Protective Services Hotline: (877) 767-2385 | Area Agency on Aging - 24 hour Senior HELPLINE: (602) 264-4357
eligibility: Seniors and their caregivers or family members
notes: Resources include information on reporting elder abuse, evaluating senior living facilities, legal assistance, business licensing verification, and connections to various state and national agencies providing senior services. The office also offers community engagement presentations on senior-related issues.

name: Arizona Child Care Resource & Referral (CCR&R)
description: Arizona Child Care Resource & Referral provides resources and support for families with young children, including help finding quality child care, parenting resources, and connections to early childhood development programs. The organization serves as a hub connecting families to various support services across Arizona.
contactInfo: Website: https://azccrr.com/ | Find Child Care: 1-800-308-9000
eligibility: Arizona families with children, particularly those with children from birth to age 5
notes: Offers connections to multiple featured organizations including Birth Through 5, Candelen, Child & Family Resources, Inc., Child Care Aware, First Things First, and Read On Arizona. Services include child care search assistance and educational resources.

name: Arizona Department of Veterans' Services - Resources
description: The Arizona Department of Veterans' Services provides a comprehensive directory of resources for veterans, including information on benefits, services, and support programs. The department connects veterans with various resources including crisis support, employment assistance, healthcare services, and educational opportunities.
contactInfo: Combat Call Center: 877-WAR-VETS (877-927-8387) | Veterans Crisis Line: 800-273-8255 | Website: https://dvs.az.gov/resources
eligibility: Veterans, service members, and their families in Arizona
notes: Offers resources in multiple categories including suicide prevention, women veterans services, employment assistance, and educational benefits. Also provides access to the Military Family Relief Fund and other veteran-specific programs.

name: Arizona Statewide Independent Living Council (AZSILC)
description: A 501(c)(3) nonprofit corporation that facilitates systemic changes to promote equality, inclusion, and choice for people with disabilities. Works strategically to strengthen and enhance the delivery of Independent Living programs, services, and concepts across Arizona.
contactInfo: 10720 W. Indian School Rd, Ste 19 #1006, Phoenix, AZ 85037 | Phone: (602) 262-2900 | Fax: (602) 271-4100
eligibility: Does not provide direct services to individuals; serves as a coordinating body for independent living resources across Arizona
notes: AZSILC promotes resources, opportunities, and experiences which empower people with disabilities to live independently. They gather public input and cultivate relationships and partnerships to maximize outcomes for people with disabilities.

name: Crisis Response Network
description: Crisis Response Network provides crisis intervention, mental health support, and resource connection for individuals experiencing homelessness or in crisis situations. They operate a 24/7 crisis hotline that connects individuals to emergency services, mental health resources, and community support programs.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness, mental health crises, or other emergency situations in Chandler and Maricopa County
notes: Crisis Response Network serves as a critical connection point for individuals in crisis, providing immediate support and referrals to appropriate community resources. They can help connect homeless individuals to emergency shelter, mental health services, and other essential support services.

name: Family Housing Hub
description: The City of Chandler supports shelters for families experiencing homelessness by collaborating with A New Leaf and Save the Family. The Family Housing Hub serves as a centralized access point for families seeking emergency shelter and housing assistance.
eligibility: Families with children experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Chandler
notes: Families should call the Family Housing Hub directly to access shelter services. The program connects families to appropriate shelter options based on their specific needs and circumstances.

name: City of Chandler Homeless Assistance Resource Guide
description: A comprehensive resource guide for homeless individuals in Chandler, providing information on food banks, shelters, housing assistance, shower facilities, clothing resources, employment services, and other support services available in the East Valley.
contactInfo: Neighborhood Resources Department, 235 S. Arizona Ave., Chandler, AZ 85225 | Phone: 480-782-4349 | Website: forcitychandler.org
eligibility: Homeless individuals and families in Chandler and surrounding areas
notes: The guide includes contact information, hours of operation, and specific services for multiple organizations including Matthew's Crossing Food Bank, Salvation Army, AZCEND I-HELP, The Clothes Cabin, and more. Resources are categorized by type of service (food, shelter, clothing, etc.) and population served (families with children, single adults).

name: Interfaith Homeless Emergency Lodging Program (I-HELP)
description: I-HELP provides emergency shelter, meals, and case management services to homeless adults in Chandler. The program offers a safe place to sleep and a hot meal every night of the week, along with access to a mobile shower unit called the 'Chandler Clean Machine.' Case management services connect individuals to resources needed to regain stability and break the cycle of homelessness.
contactInfo: For Our City Chandler | Email: volunteer@azcend.org | Phone: 480-963-1423 ext. 102
eligibility: Homeless adults in Chandler
notes: The program has successfully supported nearly 50% of clients to employment and over 30% to housing. I-HELP provides over 6,700 emergency shelter nights annually and involves hundreds of volunteers contributing more than 14,000 volunteer hours per year.

name: Control Alt Delete
description: Control Alt Delete is a nonprofit organization focused on removing the barriers that prevent domestic violence survivors from fleeing abusive relationships. They provide emergency assistance including cab rides, hotel accommodations, home security systems, lock change assistance, meals, storage and moving services.
contactInfo: Phoenix, Arizona metro area | Contact via web form at https://dvcontrolaltdelete.org/gethelp/
eligibility: Domestic violence victims seeking to escape abusive relationships; requires a direct referral for all services
notes: 98% of domestic abuse victims suffer financial abuse, which is the #1 reason why domestic violence survivors stay with their abusers. Control Alt Delete focuses on providing immediate financial and practical assistance to help victims escape.

name: Arizona Department of Child Safety Youth Resources
description: A comprehensive directory of resources for youth currently in or formerly in foster care, providing support for education, housing, advocacy, and successful transition to adulthood.
contactInfo: Email: YouthServices@azdcs.gov | Youth Empowerment Council: DCSYEC@azdcs.gov
eligibility: Young people currently experiencing foster care, as well as youth who formerly experienced foster care (especially ages 16-21)
notes: Resources include advocacy services through DCS Youth Advocates, Youth Empowerment Council participation, community-based housing options, financial literacy support, and connections to various helplines and community organizations. The program also provides information on resolving complaints, understanding foster youth rights, and accessing community-based support for employment, healthy relationships, and LGBTQ resources.
languageSupport: English, additional languages may be available through specific programs

name: Arizona Department of Economic Security - Community Resources
description: The Arizona Department of Economic Security provides a comprehensive directory of community resources for low-income families, including assistance programs for food, housing, healthcare, employment, and other basic needs. The directory includes links to various state and federal programs as well as nonprofit organizations.
contactInfo: Arizona Department of Economic Security | https://des.az.gov/services/child-and-family/community-resources
eligibility: Arizona residents seeking assistance with basic needs
notes: The DES Community Resources page contains links to external websites that provide various types of assistance. Users can download the Arizona Resource List or filter resources by category to find specific types of help.

name: DisabilityResources.org - Arizona Resources
description: A comprehensive directory of disability services and resources in Arizona, covering employment services, independent living services, rehabilitation services, and more for individuals with disabilities.
contactInfo: DisabilityResources.org website
eligibility: Individuals with disabilities in Arizona
notes: The directory includes information about various organizations providing services in different categories: employment services (RISE Services, What Can You Do Campaign), independent living services (AZSILC, Ability360, ASSIST to Independence), rehabilitation services (Arizona Rehabilitation Services Administration, Disability Rights Arizona), and more.

name: Disability Rights Arizona
description: The protection and advocacy agency for Arizonans with disabilities. A non-profit public interest law firm dedicated to protecting the rights of individuals with a wide range of physical, mental, psychiatric, sensory and cognitive disabilities.
contactInfo: Phoenix Office: 5025 E. Washington St., Suite 202, Phoenix, AZ 85034 | Phone: (602) 274-6287 | Toll Free: (800) 927-2260 | Email: center@disabilityrightsaz.org
eligibility: Individuals with disabilities in Arizona whose legal rights have been violated or who have experienced abuse or neglect
serviceArea: State-wide (Arizona) with offices in Phoenix and Tucson
notes: Follows an intake process to determine if a case meets criteria for services. Provides self-advocacy resources, legal representation, and education on disability rights. Does not create attorney-client relationships through initial contact.

name: Disability Toolkit - Resources in Arizona
description: A comprehensive toolkit created by Jewish Family & Children's Services (JFCS) and Gesher Disability Resources that provides information and expectations for families with a disabled child or adult who find themselves having to care for a person and don't know what to do.
contactInfo: Jewish Family and Children's Services (JFCS) and Gesher Disability Resources (Gesher)
eligibility: Anyone living in Arizona caring for a person with disabilities
notes: The toolkit addresses frequently asked questions including: what questions to ask, who to call, ALTCS/DDD options, medical services, educational alternatives, vocational rehabilitation, residential options, Social Security, ABLE accounts, and finding advocates/navigators.

name: Fellowship Square - Resources for Low-Income Seniors
description: A comprehensive directory of resources for low-income seniors in Phoenix and Arizona, including food assistance programs, healthcare assistance, energy assistance, and community services.
contactInfo: Christian Care Manors, 11830 N 19th Ave, Phoenix, AZ 85029 | Phone: 602-833-5057
eligibility: Low-income seniors, typically age 60 and older
serviceArea: Phoenix and surrounding areas in Maricopa County
notes: Includes information on Arizona Farmers Market Nutrition Program, Commodity Supplemental Food Program, State Health Insurance Assistance Program, Senior Medicare Patrol, energy assistance programs through Maricopa County, and Area Agencies on Aging services.

name: Gilbert Adaptive Recreation Program
description: A comprehensive adaptive recreation program offering a wide variety of activities and programs for participants of all ages with adaptive recreation needs, with an emphasis on inclusion, self-expression, and building lifelong friendships.
contactInfo: Taryn Cantrell | Phone: 480-316-5645 | Email available through website contact form
eligibility: Participants of all ages with adaptive recreation needs
notes: The program offers weekly activities including craft and art classes, exercise and wellness programs, lifestyle programs, and social activities. They also participate in Special Olympics Arizona with the Gilbert Wildcats team competing in various sports. Monthly activities include paint parties, bingo social nights, themed dances, movie nights, fieldtrips, and more. The program is a Certified Autism Center™ (CAC) designated by the International Board of Credentialing and Continuing Education Standards (IBCCES).

name: Gilbert Senior Center
description: A comprehensive senior center located inside the Gilbert Community Center that provides programs, meal service, field trips and more for seniors over the age of 55.
contactInfo: 130 N. Oak Street, Gilbert, AZ 85233 | Phone: 480-503-6061 | Hours: M-F, 8 AM-3:30 PM
eligibility: Seniors over the age of 55
notes: The center offers daily hot lunches or soup and salad from 11:30 AM - 12:30 PM. Those 60+ or under 60 with disabilities may choose a meal for a suggested contribution of $3.50; for those under 60 there is a charge of $5.00. Home Delivered Meals are also available for homebound seniors through AZCEND. The center is closed on all major holidays.

name: Gilbert Community Center Youth Programs
description: The Gilbert Community Center offers various recreation programs and activities for youth and teens, including classes, events, and social activities. The center provides a safe and welcoming environment for young people to engage in recreational activities, develop skills, and build relationships.
contactInfo: 130 N. Oak Street, Gilbert, AZ 85233 | Phone: 480-503-6290 | https://www.gilbertaz.gov/departments/parks-and-recreation/recreation-centers-classes/gilbert-community-center
eligibility: Youth and teens in Gilbert and surrounding areas
notes: Programs may include arts and crafts, sports, educational activities, and special events. Check the Gilbert Parks and Recreation website for current program offerings and registration information.

name: House of Refuge
description: A transitional housing program providing supportive services for families experiencing homelessness since 1996. The program offers wrap-around support programs to help families regain their dignity, heal from trauma, find employment, and ultimately obtain stable housing.
contactInfo: 6935 E. Williams Field Rd., Mesa, Arizona 85212 | Phone: 480-988-9242 | Email: info@houseofrefuge.org
eligibility: Families experiencing homelessness
notes: The program began in 1996 when 88 homes in the decommissioned Williams Air Force Base were converted to transitional housing. Success metrics include: 89% of participating families graduated to stable housing, 88% of adult heads of households were actively employed at graduation, and 39% of participating families increased their household income prior to graduation.
languageSupport: English, Spanish resources may be available

name: JFCS Shelter Without Walls
description: Jewish Family & Children's Service (JFCS) Shelter Without Walls program is a non-residential service that offers support to survivors of domestic violence who wish to live independently. The program provides safety planning, resources, lay legal advocacy, support groups, counseling, and comprehensive case management.
contactInfo: Phone: 602-452-4640 | Spanish Assistance: 602-534-3087
eligibility: Survivors of domestic violence of all ages, faiths, gender orientations and backgrounds
notes: Services include step-by-step safety planning, shelter referrals, crime victim information, employment assistance, legal advocacy, court accompaniment, support groups, counseling, and immigration assistance. All cases are handled in strict confidence.

name: Key Campus (Formerly Human Services Campus)
description: Key Campus (formerly Human Services Campus) is a centralized resource hub providing comprehensive services for individuals experiencing homelessness. The Brian Garcia Welcome Center offers mental health, medical and dental services, employment assistance, identification, legal help, and many other services. The campus serves as a coordinated entry point for various homeless services in Phoenix.
contactInfo: 206 S. 12th Avenue, Phoenix, AZ 85007 | Phone: 602-229-5155 | Crisis Line: 1-800-631-1314
eligibility: Single adults without children, families with young children, homeless youth (age 12-17), veterans
notes: Open 24 hours a day, every day. For single adults without children, call 211. For families with young children under 18, call Family Housing Hub at 602-595-8700. For homeless youth (12-17), call 24/7 Youth Hotline at 602-841-5799. There is always a waiting list for shelter.

name: La Mesita Family Homeless Shelter
description: A family homeless shelter in Mesa that provides temporary housing and support services for families experiencing homelessness. The shelter has 16 units and is the only shelter in the East Valley that allows parents to bring their children with them.
contactInfo: 2245 W Ella St Mesa, AZ 85201 | Family Housing Hub: (877) 211-8661 | Individual Services: (877) 211-8661
eligibility: Families with children experiencing homelessness
serviceArea: City-specific (Mesa) with focus on East Valley
notes: Families can stay up to 120 days in 1 or 2-bedroom apartments. When a family arrives, they are immediately provided with essentials: food boxes, resources on SNAP food stamps, basic sanitary products, and fresh linens. The shelter connects families to resources needed for long-term stability.

name: LGBTQIA+ Resources & Support - Autism Society of Greater Phoenix
description: A comprehensive directory of LGBTQ+ resources in Phoenix and Arizona, with a focus on supporting individuals who are both autistic and LGBTQ+. Includes information on local organizations, support groups, and community services.
contactInfo: Autism Society of Greater Phoenix
eligibility: LGBTQ+ individuals in Phoenix and Arizona, with specific resources for those who are both autistic and LGBTQ+
notes: Features multiple local resources including Phoenix Pride, Equality Arizona, GLSEN-Arizona, LGBTQ Awareness Group of AZ, and one-n-ten youth services. Also provides access to the LGBTQIA+ Arizona Resource Guide created by Arizona Coalition to End Sexual Violence's Rainbow Collective.

name: Maricopa County Senior Adult Independent Living (SAIL)
description: A program providing quality case management services coordinating home and community-based resources and services for individuals aged 60 and older and adults aged 18 to 59 with physical disabilities.
contactInfo: Contact through Area Agency on Aging referral system
eligibility: Individuals aged 60 and older and adults aged 18 to 59 with physical disabilities receiving or in the application process for SSI/Disability payments. Priority given to individuals with the greatest economic and social needs.
notes: SAIL case managers provide person-centered planning to assist each individual based on their needs. The program aims to ensure individuals can continue living independently in their homes in a safe and healthy environment for as long as possible. Services include case management and linking to additional services such as home-delivered meals, home nursing, and other community resources.

name: City of Mesa Accessibility Services
description: The City of Mesa's accessibility program ensures inclusive and equal opportunity for persons with disabilities in all aspects of community life, in compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).
contactInfo: Phone: 480-644-5034 | AzRelay: 7-1-1 | Email: togethermesa.info@mesaaz.gov | Address: City of Mesa ADA Coordinator, c/o Andrea Alicoate, PO Box 1466, Mesa, AZ 85211
eligibility: Persons with disabilities
notes: Services include ADA compliance, grievance procedures for disability discrimination complaints, and reasonable accommodations. The City ensures that its programs, services, and activities are readily accessible and usable by qualified persons with disabilities. Accommodations such as large print, Braille, ASL interpreter or other accessibility needs are available upon request.
languageSupport: English, additional accommodations available upon request

name: Mesa Family Resource Center
description: A community hub for families with children ages birth to five, offering a wide range of free parenting activities, referrals to support and resources geared towards supporting a child's optimal health and development, and community resources.
contactInfo: Phone: 480-644-6496 | Email: MFRCinfo@mesaaz.gov | Location: Main Library, 64 E. 1st St., Mesa, AZ 85201
eligibility: Families with children ages birth to five
notes: Services include parenting and child activities, referrals to community resources, and parenting education classes. Located on the Lower Level of the Main Library. Monthly programming calendars are available on the website.
languageSupport: English, additional languages may be available

name: City of Mesa Homeless Resources
description: A comprehensive directory of resources for individuals experiencing homelessness in Mesa, including helplines, emergency services, shelter information, and partner organizations providing support services.
contactInfo: Mesa Homeless Resource Line: 480-644-HOPE (4673)
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Mesa
notes: Features multiple resources including emergency helplines, family homeless resources, domestic violence shelters, veteran services, and connections to partner organizations such as Community Bridges, Mesa United Way, Paz de Cristo, St. Vincent de Paul, Save the Family, A New Leaf, House of Refuge, Circle the City, and Phoenix Rescue Mission.
languageSupport: English, translation services may be available through partner organizations

name: City of Mesa Limited Income Assistance Programs
description: A comprehensive directory of services and programs for Mesa residents with limited income, including assistance with utilities, housing, maintenance and repair, food, activities, and health services.
contactInfo: City of Mesa | Website: https://www.mesaaz.gov/Resident-Resources/Limited-Income-Assistance-Programs
eligibility: Mesa residents with limited income; specific eligibility requirements vary by program
notes: Many of the programs require application and qualification processes. The directory includes links to various assistance categories including utilities, housing, maintenance and repair, food, activities, and health services. For additional assistance programs throughout Arizona, residents are directed to 2-1-1 Arizona.
languageSupport: English, translation services may be available

name: Off the Streets Program
description: A temporary housing program with strong support services offered by Mesa and Community Bridges, Inc. The program serves Mesa's most vulnerable including seniors, Veterans, families with young children and single women.
contactInfo: Mesa Homeless Resource Line: 480-644-HOPE (4673) | Email: hope@mesaaz.gov
eligibility: Mesa's most vulnerable residents experiencing homelessness, including seniors, Veterans, families with young children, and single women
notes: As of May 2023, more than 1,700 individuals and families have been served, with 74% of program participants successfully graduating to the next step in their housing plan. The program serves individuals with various needs: 42% have physical disabilities, 12% are aged 62+, 18% are youth under 18, 21% are survivors of domestic violence, and 4% are Veterans.

name: Mesa Salvation Army - Provide Shelter
description: The Salvation Army Mesa Corps provides emergency shelter, transitional housing, and support services for individuals and families experiencing homelessness in Mesa.
contactInfo: Mesa Salvation Army Corps | Website: https://mesa.salvationarmy.org/mesa_corps/provide-shelter/
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness in Mesa
notes: Services include group homes, emergency shelters, and transitional living centers providing housing, food, and overnight lodging for varying amounts of time to those in need.

name: Mesa Vet Center
description: A VA facility offering confidential help for Veterans, service members, and their families at no cost in a non-medical setting, providing counseling for needs such as depression, PTSD, and military sexual trauma (MST).
contactInfo: Direct line available | 24/7 Call Center: 877-927-8387 | Veterans Crisis Line: 988 (press 1)
eligibility: Veterans, service members, and their families
serviceArea: City-specific (Mesa) with services available to surrounding areas
notes: Services include individual and group counseling for Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans, Vietnam Veterans, spouses/significant others, and military sexual trauma survivors. Also provides referrals to substance use treatment, homelessness resources, and other community services. Hours: Monday-Thursday 8:00am-4:30pm, Friday 8:00am-4:00pm, Closed weekends.

name: Mesa Veteran Resource Center
description: A one-stop location for veterans to connect with the resources they need, serving as a centralized hub for veteran services in Mesa.
contactInfo: Mesa, AZ, 85201 | Website: https://mesavrc.org/
eligibility: Veterans and their families
notes: The center aims to be a comprehensive resource hub where veterans can access various services and support programs. Partners with HandsOn Greater Phoenix for volunteer opportunities. Impact areas include Health & Wellness.

name: Mesa Vets Connect - Veterans Resources
description: A comprehensive directory of resources for veterans in Mesa, providing connections to emergency services, local support, and national veteran assistance programs.
contactInfo: National Veterans Crisis Line: 1-800-273-8255, option 1 | Text: 838255 | Arizona Coalition for Military Families: 602-753-8802 | Help for Homeless Veterans Line: 1-877-424-3838
eligibility: Veterans, service members, and their families
serviceArea: City-specific (Mesa) with connections to East Valley, Arizona, and national resources
notes: Resources are organized by geographic scope (City of Mesa, East Valley, Arizona, National) and include emergency contacts, crisis support, housing assistance, and general veteran services. The program is part of the Military/Veteran Resource Network.

name: City of Mesa Prosecutor Victim Services Unit
description: The Victim Services Unit (VSU) serves victims of crimes in Mesa, including domestic violence victims, providing essential information on victims' rights, criminal justice procedures, and support in accessing resources for emotional and physical healing, safety and security, and economic recovery.
contactInfo: Phone: 480-644-2188 | Servicios Para Víctimas: 480-644-2188 | Fax: 480-644-2584 | Email: VSU@mesaaz.gov
eligibility: Victims of crimes in Mesa, including domestic violence victims, as well as Mesa residents seeking assistance with victimization (reporting a crime, obtaining a protective order, safety planning, etc.)
notes: VSU staff are dedicated to connecting victims with information and support needed to navigate the criminal justice system. Hours: Monday - Thursday, 7:00 am to 6:00 pm. Services available in English and Spanish.

name: M.E.S.A. (Making Every Student Accountable)
description: A unique program for at-risk youth developed by the Mesa Police Department, Mesa Public Schools, and local businesses and agencies to help students who are in danger of dropping out of school, joining gangs, or facing other serious challenges.
contactInfo: Contact through Mesa Police Department Youth Development Unit
eligibility: At-risk junior high school students, particularly from Kino Junior High School area
notes: M.E.S.A. operates a 9-week after-school program twice a year that includes classroom curriculum, community service, team building, and family engagement. The program teaches life skills including self-reflection, wellness, proper exercise, nutrition, hygiene, etiquette, goal setting, and resume building. Family engagement is a key component, with parent sessions every Tuesday night. The program has shown success in keeping 77% of participants in public high school.

name: Mesa Community Action Network (MesaCAN)
description: A comprehensive program that helps low-income households across the City of Mesa with a host of services promoting financial wellness, including financial assistance, educational assistance, employment assistance, health assistance, and other resources.
contactInfo: Contact via A New Leaf | Website: https://turnanewleaf.org/services/financial-empowerment/mesacan/
eligibility: Low-income households in Mesa
notes: MesaCAN offers over 15 separate resources including financial assistance, employment assistance, health assistance, educational assistance, and additional community resources. Services are designed to strengthen the Mesa community and build a stronger community for households in need.

name: Money Fit Low-Income Resources in Arizona
description: A comprehensive directory of low-income assistance resources in Arizona, organized into four categories: Food, Housing/Utilities, Child/Family Care, and Healthcare, with detailed information about each program.
contactInfo: Phone: (800) 432-0310 | Website: https://www.moneyfit.org/low-income/arizona-resources/
eligibility: Low-income residents of Arizona; specific eligibility requirements vary by program
notes: The directory includes resources for nutrition assistance, housing support, healthcare services, and family assistance programs. Each resource includes a brief description, contact information such as phone numbers and website URLs. Money Fit also offers debt management services and financial education resources.

name: Olmstead Rights - Arizona Disability Resources and Advocacy Organizations
description: A comprehensive directory of disability resources and advocacy organizations in Arizona, categorized by service type and providing links to government agencies and disability rights organizations.
contactInfo: Olmstead Rights website
eligibility: People with disabilities in Arizona and their caregivers
notes: Includes information on Protection & Advocacy Organizations, Aging and Disability Resource Centers, Legal Services Organizations, Independent Living Councils, Crisis Services, Developmental Disabilities Services, Mental Health Services, Physical Disabilities Services, and more specialized resources.

name: one·n·ten
description: A nonprofit organization dedicated to serving and assisting LGBTQ+ youth and young adults ages 11-24. Provides empowering social and service programs that promote self-expression, self-acceptance, leadership development, and healthy life choices.
contactInfo: Downtown Youth Center in Phoenix | Website: https://onenten.org/
eligibility: LGBTQ+ youth and young adults ages 11-24
serviceArea: State-wide (Arizona) with locations in Phoenix, Flagstaff, Yuma, and other cities
notes: Offers various programs including youth welcome meetings, social activities, leadership development, and safe spaces for LGBTQ+ youth to connect with peers. Also operates POND Housing for LGBTQ+ youth experiencing homelessness.

name: City of Phoenix Disability Resources
description: A comprehensive resource directory for individuals with disabilities in Phoenix, providing information on accessible city services, transportation options, housing, recreation, and ADA compliance programs.
contactInfo: Phoenix City Hall, 200 W. Washington Street, Phoenix, AZ 85003 | Main: 602-262-3111 | Water/Sewer/City Services: 602-262-6251 | TTY: 711
eligibility: Individuals with disabilities in Phoenix
notes: Offers resources in multiple categories including accessible transportation, housing options, adaptive recreation programs, and ADA compliance information. Documents are available in alternative formats upon request.

name: City of Phoenix Family Advocacy Center
description: The City of Phoenix Family Advocacy Center provides comprehensive support services for victims of domestic violence, including mobile victim advocates who can assist with resources, referrals, and navigating the legal system. The center connects victims with emergency services, protective orders, and other vital resources.
contactInfo: Phone: (602) 534-2120 | Mobile Victim Advocate Maryvale: (602) 647-5411 | Mobile Victim Advocate South Phoenix: (602) 647-2662
eligibility: Victims of domestic violence in Phoenix
notes: Mobile Victim Advocates are available Monday - Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. The center provides connections to multiple domestic violence hotlines and resources.

name: Phoenix Pride Resources
description: A comprehensive directory of local LGBTQ+ resources in Phoenix, AZ, including social/support groups, health/human resources, support organizations, sports, publications, bars, restaurants, and faith-based services to assist the LGBTQ+ community, their friends, educators, parents, and family members.
eligibility: LGBTQ+ individuals and allies in Phoenix and surrounding areas
notes: Features numerous local LGBTQ+ organizations including Arizona Gaymers, Arizona Men of Leather, Arizona Trans Masculine Society, Bears of the West, Desert Overture, Grand Canyon Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence, and many others. Also provides information on LGBTQ-friendly businesses and venues throughout Phoenix.

name: City of Phoenix Refugee and Immigrant Support
description: A comprehensive resource directory provided by the City of Phoenix Human Services Department, offering information about immigrant and refugee communities, resettlement agencies, and support services available in Phoenix.
contactInfo: City of Phoenix Human Services Department
eligibility: Immigrants and refugees in Phoenix
notes: Phoenix hosts four resettlement agencies: International Rescue Committee (IRC), Arizona Immigrant Refugee Services (AIRS), Catholic Charities (CC), and Lutheran Social Services. The city is committed to providing support for refugees and immigrants to help them integrate into the community.
languageSupport: Multiple languages available through translation services

name: Phoenix Rescue Mission - Hope Coach
description: Phoenix Rescue Mission's Hope Coach program provides street outreach to individuals experiencing homelessness across Maricopa County. Their mobile outreach vehicles travel throughout the Valley offering water, hygiene items, seasonal necessities, and connections to recovery programs and housing solutions.
contactInfo: 1801 S. 35th Ave., Phoenix, AZ 85009 | Phone: 602-233-3000 | Hope Coach Direct Line: 602-346-3361
eligibility: Anyone experiencing homelessness; faith-based organization
serviceArea: Phoenix metropolitan area and Maricopa County
notes: The outreach team consists of peer support certified case managers, many of whom have overcome homelessness or addiction themselves. They help connect individuals to housing, recovery programs, and other essential services.

name: Phoenix Vet Center
description: The Phoenix Vet Center offers confidential help for Veterans, service members, and their families at no cost in a non-medical setting. Services include counseling for depression, post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), military sexual trauma (MST), and connections to additional VA and community resources.
contactInfo: 4020 North 20th Street, Suite 110, Phoenix, AZ 85016 | Direct line: 602-640-2981 | 24/7 Call Center: 877-927-8387
eligibility: Veterans, active duty service members, and their families
notes: Services include individual and group counseling, family counseling, bereavement counseling, military sexual trauma counseling, and transition assistance. Non-traditional hours available by request.

name: PHX C.A.R.E.S. (Community Action Response Engagement Services)
description: A coordinated response for neighborhoods and individuals experiencing homelessness—offering education, resources, and encampment cleanups. PHX C.A.R.E.S. is the city's process of connecting the community with services like encampment cleanups, shelters, and other resources for individuals and families experiencing homelessness.
contactInfo: 602-262-6251 | Monday-Saturday 8 a.m. - 5 p.m.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness in Phoenix
notes: City-run program that coordinates homeless services and community response

name: Revive Community Health - Community Resources
description: A comprehensive directory of resources for immigrants and refugees in Phoenix and Tucson, including information on health services, legal assistance, employment support, and educational opportunities.
contactInfo: Email: [email protected] | Phone: (480) 851-6309
eligibility: Immigrants and refugees in Phoenix and Tucson areas
notes: Features multiple resource categories including International Rescue Committee services, Arizona Refugee Career Pathways program, Immigration Legal Services for Afghan Arrivals (ILSAA), and connections to health resources, vaccine clinics, education & career development, legal resources, housing assistance, domestic violence support, and food assistance.

name: The Salvation Army Phoenix Family Services
description: The Salvation Army Phoenix Family Services provides support to families in need through various programs including food assistance, utility assistance, rental assistance, and homeless family outreach. They work to address both immediate needs and root causes of poverty.
contactInfo: Phone: 602-267-4122 | Utility/Rental Assistance: 602-267-4127 | Hours: Monday-Friday 8:00am-2:00pm
eligibility: Residents of Phoenix; specific eligibility requirements vary by program
notes: Food boxes available once per month with ID; additional ready-to-eat food bags available daily without ID. Utility assistance for SRP-APS-SWG within Phoenix. Services available in English and Spanish.

name: Teen Lifeline Local Resources
description: A comprehensive directory of resources for teens and families available throughout Arizona, covering topics including suicide/crisis intervention, general counseling, sexuality, runaway support, abuse/sexual assault, and pregnancy/STD services.
contactInfo: Call/Text: 602-248-TEEN (8336) | Website: teenlifeline.org
eligibility: Teenagers and their families
notes: Teen Lifeline offers a crisis line where teens can talk to trained peer counselors (ages 15-19) from 3pm-9pm daily, and to adult counselors at other times. The website provides an extensive directory of local resources organized by category, including hotlines, support services, and specialized programs for various teen issues.

name: UMOM New Day Centers
description: UMOM provides shelter, services and affordable housing for single women and families experiencing homelessness in the Metro Phoenix area. Their programs are built around a formula of jobs + housing = ending homelessness, offering emergency shelter, transitional housing, and permanent supportive housing.
contactInfo: 3333 East Van Buren Street, Phoenix, AZ 85008 | Phone: 602-275-7852 | Crisis Line: 602-222-9444
eligibility: Families with dependent children, single women without children (including victims of domestic violence)
notes: The Family Housing Hub (FHH) is a single point of entry for families in Maricopa County to access shelter. UMOM's Halle Women's Center serves single women without children. Waiting lists are common.

name: USCIS Afghan Support Center Resources - Phoenix
description: A comprehensive directory of resources for Afghan immigrants and refugees in Phoenix, organized by service categories including child and youth services, education, employment, government assistance, health, housing, legal services, and more.
contactInfo: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS)
eligibility: Afghan immigrants and refugees in Phoenix area
notes: Features over 30 service providers across multiple categories, including City of Phoenix Head Start, Arizona Career Pathways, Lutheran Social Services of the Southwest, ICNA Relief, Phoenix College, Valleywise Center for Refugee and Global Health, and Immigration Legal Services for Afghan Arrivals (ILSAA).

name: U.S.VETS Phoenix
description: U.S.VETS Phoenix provides comprehensive services for veterans transitioning from homelessness to housing, including transitional housing, permanent housing assistance, mental health services, career development, and case management services to help veterans regain and maintain independence.
contactInfo: Outreach Team: 602-757-9723 or 602-859-7329 | Supportive Services for Veteran Families: 602-441-0612 | Location: Grand Veterans Village
eligibility: Veterans experiencing homelessness or at risk of becoming homeless
notes: Home to 152 veterans transitioning from homelessness to housing, and 30 low-income rentals. Special program for low-income veteran families who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.

name: Visiting Angels Mesa
description: A non-medical in-home care agency providing personalized services to seniors and disabled individuals throughout Mesa and surrounding areas, allowing them to remain safely in their homes.
contactInfo: Phone: 480-833-8247 | Address: Mesa, AZ
eligibility: Seniors and disabled individuals needing assistance with daily living activities
serviceArea: Mesa, Tempe, Apache Junction, Queen Creek, Gold Canyon, San Tan Valley, Florence, Chandler, and Gilbert
notes: Services include help with errands, bathing, dressing, grooming, grocery shopping, meal preparation, transportation to appointments, medication reminders, walking assistance, fall prevention, light housekeeping, and companionship. Offers specialty care for those with Alzheimer's and dementia. Provides no-cost care consultations.

name: Valley of the Sun United Way - Project Connect
description: Valley of the Sun United Way works with partners to decrease housing insecurity by investing in rent and utility assistance, housing navigators and eviction prevention. Project Connect makes it simple for individuals or families experiencing or near homelessness to connect to vital services in one location.
contactInfo: 3200 E Camelback Rd, Suite 375, Phoenix, AZ 85018 | Phone: 602-631-4800 | Email: information@vsuw.org | https://vsuw.org/our-work/housing-and-homelessness/
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing or at risk of homelessness in Maricopa County
notes: VSUW coordinates with numerous partner organizations including Central Arizona Shelter Services, Human Services Campus, UMOM, and many others to provide comprehensive services.

name: Teen LGBTQ+ Support Group - Strategies for Success
description: A support group for LGBTQ+ teens in Chandler, providing a safe space to connect with others who are questioning or identify as LGBTQ+. The group discusses family, relationships, communication, self advocacy, health and other relevant topics.
eligibility: Teens who are questioning or identify as LGBTQ+
contactInfo: Phone: (602) 428-9078 | Group meets in Chandler, AZ 85248 | Hosted by Strategies for Success
notes: Led by a Clinical Social Worker/Therapist with credentials MD, LCSW, PsyNP, PMHNP. Focuses on building community and providing support for LGBTQ+ youth.

name: Transgender(LGBTQ+) Support Group With Mary Brasch
description: A monthly in-person transgender support group with 20 years of continuous support for the Trans (LGBTQ+) community in Chandler. The group provides free support in a safe, welcoming environment.
eligibility: Transgender and LGBTQ+ individuals
notes: Long-established support group (20+ years) funded by a donor to provide free support services to the transgender community.

name: Gilbert Housing Assistance Programs
description: A comprehensive set of housing assistance programs for individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Gilbert, including emergency rental assistance, home repair help, and affordable housing resources.
eligibility: Gilbert residents experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness
contactInfo: Gilbert Community Resources Division | Town Manager's Office
notes: Provides multiple housing assistance options including emergency rental assistance, minor home repair programs, and connections to affordable housing resources. Part of Gilbert's Community Resources division aimed at improving quality of life for residents.

name: Glendale Homeless Services
description: A comprehensive resource directory for individuals experiencing homelessness in Glendale, providing information on coordinated entry points, emergency shelter, and support services through the city's Community Services division.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Glendale
contactInfo: Brian Garcia Welcome Center (for individuals): 206 S 12th Avenue, Phoenix AZ, 85007, Phone: (602) 229-5155 | UMOM Family Housing Hub (for families with minor children): 3307 E Van Buren Street, Phoenix AZ, 85008, Phone: (877) 211-8661
notes: Provides coordinated entry services connecting individuals to appropriate housing and support services. Includes downloadable resource fliers with information on housing, food, hygiene, and mental health services. Some programs may open and close throughout the year based on available funding.

name: Housing Authority of Maricopa County - Avondale Office
description: A county housing authority office located in Avondale that provides housing assistance programs, Section 8 vouchers, and other housing resources for low-income individuals and families experiencing or at risk of homelessness.
eligibility: Low-income individuals and families experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness
contactInfo: 525 E. Harrison St., Avondale, AZ 85323 | Phone: 623-925-0770
notes: Provides access to Section 8 housing vouchers, public housing programs, and other housing assistance services throughout Maricopa County.

name: Scottsdale Community Partners Homeless Services
description: A collaborative program between the City of Scottsdale and local non-profit agencies providing comprehensive services for individuals experiencing homelessness, including day relief centers, navigation services, and housing assistance.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness in Scottsdale
contactInfo: Scottsdale Community Partners - Contact available through website
notes: Provides day relief centers where people experiencing homelessness receive meals, respite, and navigation services. Navigators assist with case management, obtaining documents for employment, applying for benefits, and connecting to temporary and permanent housing opportunities. The program has achieved 180 unduplicated engagements since opening and includes street outreach throughout the community.

name: Tempe CARE and HOPE Line
description: A 24/7 dedicated phone line and outreach team that provides assistance to individuals experiencing homelessness in Tempe, connecting them to available resources and services.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Tempe
contactInfo: CARE & HOPE Line: 480-350-8004 | Email: HOPE@tempe.gov
notes: The community can call the 24/7 CARE & HOPE Line to get help for themselves or others in need. The city also provides an online reporting form and dashboard for tracking homeless solutions efforts.

name: Virtue Recovery Center Chandler
description: A comprehensive drug and alcohol addiction treatment center in Chandler offering evidence-based, individualized care for substance abuse recovery. Services include detox, inpatient treatment, and outpatient programs with specialized therapy options.
eligibility: Individuals struggling with substance abuse and addiction. Insurance verification available.
contactInfo: 111 S Hearthstone Way, Chandler, AZ 85226 | Phone: (855) 449-8557 | Email: admissions@virtuerc.com
notes: Accredited facility offering a full continuum of care from intensive inpatient to outpatient treatment. Provides various therapy programs including cognitive-behavioral therapy, dialectical behavior therapy, and group therapy.

name: Arizona Coalition to End Sexual and Domestic Violence
description: The Arizona Coalition to End Sexual and Domestic Violence (ACESDV) provides resources and support for survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault throughout Arizona. Their helpline connects survivors with appropriate services, and they offer crisis intervention, safety planning, and referrals to local resources.

name: Teen Lifeline
description: Teen Lifeline provides a safe, confidential, and crucial crisis service where teens help teens make healthy decisions. Their hotline is answered by trained peer counselors (teens 15-19) from 3pm-9pm daily, with adult counselors available during other hours. They offer crisis intervention, suicide prevention, and connections to local resources for youth throughout Arizona.

name: Catholic Charities
description: Catholic Charities provides homeless services throughout Arizona, offering emergency shelter, transitional housing, and permanent supportive housing. They work to help individuals and families experiencing homelessness find safe, stable, and affordable housing with supportive services.

name: Lutheran Social Services of the Southwest
description: Lutheran Social Services of the Southwest provides quality care that enables seniors and individuals with disabilities to live at home and maintain their highest level of independence. They offer a range of services including in-home care, caregiver support, and assistance with daily living activities.

name: Buckeye Community Action Program
description: A social services program that partners with Maricopa County Community Action Program and the Salvation Army to assist Buckeye residents during unexpected financial challenges, providing support that fosters self-sufficiency and stability.
eligibility: Buckeye residents experiencing financial hardship. Must provide photo ID, utility bills, proof of income, and crisis statement for Salvation Army assistance.
contactInfo: 110 E. Irwin Ave., Buckeye, AZ 85326 | Phone: 623-349-6619 | Portal issues: 602-506-0589 | Email: CAPbuckeye@buckeyeaz.gov
notes: Provides limited, temporary assistance with utility bills and eviction prevention, information and referral resources, and short-term case management. Walk-in hours are Tuesday, 9 a.m. - 11 a.m.

name: Buckeye Heat Relief Network
description: A regional initiative providing free, cooled spaces and hydration stations throughout Buckeye to prevent heat-related illnesses and deaths among vulnerable populations, including those experiencing homelessness.
eligibility: Open to all, particularly focused on homeless individuals and others vulnerable to heat-related illness
contactInfo: Cooling Centers at Coyote and Downtown Libraries | Multiple hydration stations in downtown Buckeye
notes: Part of the Maricopa County Department of Public Health and Maricopa Association of Governments Heat Relief Network, operating through September 30 during the hottest months of the year.

name: Care1st Avondale Resource and Housing Center
description: A resource center providing housing assistance and support services for individuals and families experiencing homelessness in Avondale and surrounding areas of Maricopa County.
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness
contactInfo: 328 W. Western Ave, Avondale, AZ 85323 | Phone: 623-333-2703
notes: Part of the coordinated entry system for homeless services in Maricopa County. Provides access to housing resources, case management, and connections to additional support services.

name: Circle the City - Community Resource Guide
description: A comprehensive resource guide for individuals facing homelessness in Maricopa County, providing information on healthcare services, housing resources, coordinated entry locations, and shelters specifically designed for the homeless population.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness in Maricopa County
contactInfo: Main Office: 602-776-9000 | Website: circlethecity.org
notes: Circle the City is a nonprofit organization providing healthcare services and resources to people experiencing homelessness throughout Maricopa County. Their resource guide includes housing resources, coordinated entry locations, and shelter information.

name: Surprise Resource Center - Community Action Program
description: A resource center that provides support services for individuals and families experiencing homelessness in El Mirage, including utility and eviction prevention assistance, heat relief, hydration stations, and connections to other support services.
eligibility: Residents of El Mirage experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness
notes: A partnership between Maricopa County, Surprise, El Mirage, and other nearby communities that provides temporary assistance and connects individuals to additional resources. Also serves as a heat relief and hydration station during summer months.

name: St. Vincent de Paul El Mirage Dining Room
description: A dining facility that serves hot meals to families and individuals experiencing homelessness in the El Mirage community.
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness in El Mirage
contactInfo: 14013 N Verbena St., El Mirage, AZ 85335 | Tony Alvarado, Dining Rooms Manager | Phone: 602-620-1892 | Email: aalvarado@svdpaz.org
notes: Part of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul network, providing direct food assistance to those experiencing homelessness in the El Mirage area.

name: Fountain Hills Homelessness Resources
description: A comprehensive directory of resources for individuals experiencing homelessness in Fountain Hills, including information on regional homelessness strategies, emergency assistance, and connections to county-wide services.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Fountain Hills
contactInfo: Fountain Hills Community Center | 13001 N La Montana Drive, Fountain Hills, AZ 85268 | Phone: 480-816-5200
notes: Provides information on regional homelessness strategies and resources, including connections to the Maricopa Association of Governments (MAG) homelessness initiatives and emergency assistance through the 211 system.

name: GoodyearCares Homeless Services
description: A comprehensive resource directory for individuals experiencing homelessness in Goodyear, providing information on emergency shelter, coordinated entry points, and support services through the city's GoodyearCares program.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Goodyear
contactInfo: Coordinated entry system varies by population - see website for specific contact points
notes: Provides information on the Interfaith Homeless Emergency Lodging Program (I-HELP), coordinated entry services, and connections to county-wide resources. Also includes information on rental assistance, utility assistance, and eviction prevention programs.

name: West Valley Housing Assistance Center
description: A comprehensive resource center providing emergency housing and services to individuals and families experiencing homelessness in the West Valley, including Litchfield Park residents.
eligibility: Individuals and families experiencing homelessness in Litchfield Park and surrounding West Valley communities
contactInfo: 623-850-5611 | 12779 W. Grand Ave, Surprise AZ 85374 | Families: WVHACinfo@turnanewleaf.org | Individuals: 877-211-8661
notes: Provides coordinated entry services, emergency housing in apartment-style units, rental and security deposit assistance, and workforce services. Serves as a West Valley entry point for Family Housing Hub shelter assessments.

name: Maricopa Association of Governments (MAG) Homelessness Resources
description: A comprehensive directory of resources for individuals experiencing homelessness in Maricopa County, including coordinated entry points, crisis services, and specialized resources for singles, families, youth, veterans, and domestic violence survivors.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Maricopa County
contactInfo: Singles: Brian Garcia Welcome Center at 602-229-5155 | Families: Family Housing Hub at 2-1-1 | Youth (12-17): Safe Place at 602-841-5799 | Veterans: Community Resource and Referral Center at 602-248-6040 | DV Survivors: SAFEDVS hotline at 480-890-3039
notes: Provides centralized access to the Maricopa County Continuum of Care system with specialized entry points based on population type (singles, families, youth, veterans, DV survivors).

name: Central Arizona Shelter Services (CASS)
description: A comprehensive shelter service provider for individuals experiencing homelessness, offering short-term shelter, meals, and related services to facilitate moving homeless individuals towards self-sufficiency.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness in Maricopa County
notes: Provides emergency shelter, case management, and supportive services to help individuals transition out of homelessness. Serves Paradise Valley residents as part of their county-wide service area.

name: PATH Program - Phoenix Community Development Services
description: A comprehensive outreach and support program for individuals experiencing homelessness or at imminent risk of homelessness who also have a serious mental illness, providing assistance with housing identification, case management, and connections to essential services.
eligibility: Individuals in Peoria who are homeless, at imminent risk of becoming homeless, do not have permanent housing AND have a serious mental illness
serviceArea: City-specific (Peoria) and surrounding counties (Tazewell, Woodford, Fulton)
contactInfo: Phoenix Community Development Services - Contact available through website
notes: Provides outreach, screening and diagnostic treatment, case management, linkage to health services, job training, educational services, and housing services. Also offers HOWIE (Hygiene On Wheels Independence Empowered), a mobile hygiene unit providing showers, toilets, and laundry access.

name: D2 Homes for the Homeless
description: A support system for individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness, providing community collaboration, hygiene bags, mental health professional connections, and rental assistance programs.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Queen Creek and surrounding areas
contactInfo: 90 South Kyrene Road, Chandler, AZ 85226 | Phone: 480-528-3075
notes: Focuses on creating support systems for those who live independently and experience temporary setbacks, with the goal of combating homelessness and reducing stigmatization of homeless individuals in Arizona.

name: Tolleson Housing Resources & Coordinated Entry Locations
description: A comprehensive listing of coordinated entry locations and housing resources for individuals experiencing homelessness in Tolleson and the surrounding Maricopa County area.
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness in Tolleson and Maricopa County
contactInfo: Multiple locations with varying contact information - See website for complete listing
notes: Provides access to multiple coordinated entry locations including Keys to Change Campus, Avondale Resource Center, UMOM New Day Centers, Tempe Community Action Agency, and Norton and Ramsey Social Justice Empowerment Center. Services include interviews to assess needs, resource connections, and housing plan development.

name: AllThrive 365 Wickenburg Healthy Aging Center
description: A comprehensive community resource center operating out of the Wellik Senior Center, providing essential services including housing assistance, utility and rental assistance, food pantry services, and community programs for families and aging adults in Wickenburg.
eligibility: Residents of Wickenburg, with specific programs for seniors and families
contactInfo: Wellik Senior Center - Contact available through website
notes: Operates the Community Action Program office connecting residents with resources like utility and rental assistance, weatherization programs, and housing with affordable rents. Also provides a food pantry and home-delivered meal program to support those in need.

name: CAAFA (Community Alliance Against Family Abuse)
description: A nonprofit organization providing support services and resources for victims of domestic and sexual violence in Apache Junction and surrounding areas.
address: Not specified - contact for location information
eligibility: Victims of domestic and sexual violence
application_process: Contact via phone for assistance and intake information
target_group: Victims of domestic violence, Victims of sexual violence

name: Community Bridges
description: A nonprofit organization providing resources and services for the homeless, those with substance abuse issues, and individuals with mental illness in Apache Junction and surrounding areas.
address: Not specified - multiple locations may be available
hours: Not specified - contact for current hours
eligibility: Individuals experiencing homelessness, substance abuse issues, or mental illness
application_process: Contact directly for service information and intake process
target_group: Homeless individuals, Individuals with substance abuse issues, Individuals with mental illness

name: Apache Junction Community Resource Center
description: A collaborative resource center that brings together social service agencies to provide on-site information, resources, and referrals for homeless and at-risk residents of Apache Junction.
address: 564 North Idaho Road, Suite 11, Apache Junction, AZ 85120
phone: Not specified - check Facebook page for current information
hours: Variable - schedule can be found on the center's Facebook page
services: Information and referrals to social services
Part of the Apache Junction Homeless Coalition
Connection to community partners and services
eligibility: Homeless and at-risk residents of Apache Junction
application_process: Walk-in service, no formal application process mentioned

name: Empowerment Systems Resource Center
description: A resource center that provides information, resources, and support services to residents of Apache Junction, with a focus on empowering individuals and families.
address: 2066 West Apache Trail, Suite 116, Apache Junction, AZ 85120
hours: Not specified - contact for current hours
eligibility: Residents of Apache Junction and surrounding areas
target_group: Low-income families, Individuals in need of resources

name: Genesis Project
description: A faith-based non-profit soup kitchen that provides free meals, clothing, and support services to the hungry and homeless in Apache Junction. All services are provided free of charge to guests.
address: 1050 W Superstition Blvd, Apache Junction, AZ 85120
hours: Monday through Friday, meals served daily
services: Hot meals served Monday through Friday
Mailing address services for those without physical addresses
eligibility: Open to all hungry and homeless individuals, no questions asked
application_process: No formal application process; walk-in service

name: Apache Junction Homeless Coalition
description: A collaborative network of organizations and agencies working together to create quality resources and services to assist the homeless and at-risk residents of Apache Junction.
address: Not specified - operates through the Community Resource Center at 564 North Idaho Road, Suite 11, Apache Junction, AZ 85120
phone: Not specified - contact through Community Resource Center
eligibility: Homeless and at-risk residents of Apache Junction
application_process: Contact through the Community Resource Center

name: HOPE Women's Center
description: A nonprofit organization providing support services and resources for women in crisis or difficult situations in the Apache Junction area.
address: Not specified - contact for location information
hours: Not specified - contact for current hours
eligibility: Women in crisis or difficult situations in the Apache Junction area
application_process: Contact via phone for assistance and service information
target_group: Women in crisis, Women experiencing difficult situations

name: Salvation Army Apache Junction
description: A nonprofit organization providing food assistance, rent/utility assistance, and other emergency services to individuals and families in need in the Apache Junction area.
address: Not specified - contact for location information
hours: Not specified - contact for current hours
eligibility: Individuals and families in need in the Apache Junction area
application_process: Contact via phone for assistance and eligibility information
target_group: Low-income families, Individuals experiencing financial hardship

name: Superstition Community Food Bank
description: A food bank providing emergency food assistance to individuals and families in need in the Apache Junction area.
address: Not specified - contact for location information
hours: Not specified - contact for current hours
eligibility: Individuals and families in need in the Apache Junction area
application_process: Contact via phone for assistance and eligibility information
target_group: Low-income families, Individuals experiencing food insecurity

name: Arizona Coalition to End Sexual and Domestic Violence (ACESDV)
description: A statewide coalition that provides support, resources, and advocacy for victims of sexual and domestic violence across Arizona. They operate a 24/7 helpline and connect survivors with local services.
phone: 602-279-2980 or 1-800-782-6400 (Arizona Sexual and Domestic Violence Helpline)
hours: 24/7 helpline; Office hours by appointment only
services: Connection to local domestic violence programs
eligibility: Victims of sexual and domestic violence in Arizona
application_process: Call helpline or contact through website

name: Arizona Coalition to End Sexual and Domestic Violence (ACESDV)
description: A statewide coalition providing support, resources, and advocacy for victims of sexual and domestic violence across Arizona. They operate the Arizona Sexual and Domestic Violence Helpline, offering multiple ways to connect with support services.
address: 2800 N. Central Ave., Suite 1570, Phoenix, AZ 85004
hours: Helpline: Mon 8:30-5, Tues 8:30-7, Wed-Fri 8:30-5; Office hours may vary
services: Referrals to local programs and shelters
eligibility: Anyone affected by sexual or domestic violence in Arizona
application_process: Contact through helpline via call, chat, SMS, or email; no formal application required

name: International Rescue Committee (IRC)
description: Nonprofit organization providing services for refugees, immigrants, vulnerable populations
services: Support for victims of human trafficking
eligibility: Refugees, immigrants, victims of human trafficking, and other vulnerable populations
service_area: Arizona, primarily Phoenix area but services extend to surrounding areas including Pisinemo
target_group: Refugees, immigrants, victims of human trafficking

name: Arizona Coalition to End Sexual and Domestic Violence (ACESDV)
description: Statewide coalition providing support and resources for sexual and domestic violence survivors through helpline services, local program connections, and resources.
eligibility: Survivors of sexual and domestic violence
accessibility: Phone, chat, SMS, and email support available
